utterance: Chris Jones: Has anybody thought about the energetics of CO2 binding? So when you look at the most successful molecules or materials out there they have strong enthalpically driven binding because of course absorption is disfavored from an entropic perspective. But of course if you're going to swing it off you've got to you've got to repay that that enthalpy penalty. So are there strategies one could employ to design more physisorbing sites that would still absorb CO2 selectively? And the nice thing about some of the inorganic or hybrid materials like MOFs is you imagine that your toolbox is huge for the types of sites that you could potentially design. So could you design a very high density of more weakly binding sites and still grab enough CO2 at these ultra dilute conditions without having to repay that massive enthalpy penalty that all these strong chemisorbing materials pay?

annotations.propose new idea: Chris Jones suggests exploring an alternative approach to CO2 binding by questioning the need for strong enthalpically driven binding and proposing the design of physisorbing sites.
annotations.ask question: Chris Jones asks for thoughts on the energetics of CO2 binding and for strategies to design more physisorbing sites.
annotations.develop idea: Chris Jones expands on the idea by discussing the potential of materials like MOFs and the concept of a high density of weakly binding sites for CO2 capture.

Charm is one of them, Clean Energy Solutions, LanzaTech to some extent. But these these companies you know one of the things and and you might categorize this as BECCS a little bit. And so we we're familiar with things like blue hydrogen and green hydrogen but in the case of if you're using a biomass waste to produce hydrogen and in the production of that hydrogen you you separate out the CO2 and you store it you have the potential of producing negative hydrogen. And I think that you know that's something that's kind of new and I don't know if that's something you guys have given any thought to as an alternative source of hydrogen and it is a way of taking water out of the air because you're essentially using and exploiting photosynthesis right and CO2 of course. And there are some companies that are kind of thinking about this but not selling it in that way. But that's interesting. It's also just regional so you have to be careful because how much biomass waste is there out there? You know there's no silver bullet. But a little seed I want to plant if you haven't been thinking about that.

annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces a new perspective on hydrogen production through biomass waste conversion.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker elaborates on the concept, providing details on its potential and implications.
annotations.ask question: The speaker seeks input or discussion on the idea presented.
